Legal_Issue: Was the Officer's decision reasonable, and did it breach procedural fairness by denying an oral interview?
Governing_Law: Standard of review for H&C decisions is reasonableness
Evidence_Assessment: Officer acknowledged hardships but found insufficient evidence of disproportionate hardship or lack of support in Korea; psychologist's opinion was not binding
Credibility_Factor: Psychologist's opinion considered but not deemed binding
Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness does not always require an oral hearing
Grounds_for_Claim: Refusal of H&C application and denial of procedural fairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Hardships claimed by applicant, psychologist's report
Applicant_Challenge: Refusal of H&C application and denial of oral interview
Legal_Rule_Source: Federal Court jurisprudence on standard of review
Defendant_Response: Guidelines are not law and do not create legal entitlements
Remedy_Requested: Certification of serious question and allowance of judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal of H&C application and obtain oral hearing
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to H&C
Applicable_Process: Administrative decision-making followed by judicial review
Governing_Rule: Reasonableness standard applies to H&C decisions
